data.title: The Magic of Aperitivo: How Drinking Like an Italian Can Enhance Your Well-Being
data.meta_description: It’s more than happy hour. In this episode, we learn how this social ritual can foster connection, community and more.
data.text:
In Italy, time with family and friends isn’t reserved for special occasions. It is a daily priority, often cultivated through aperitivo.

On the surface, aperitivo is a pre-dinner ritual centered around small bites and a sensible amount of booze. It’s a fabulous excuse to show off your cooking skills with unexpected stuzzichini and wine pairings, or sip casually on a Hugo spritz. But the true meaning runs deeper.

According to Stef Ferrari, author of Stuzzichini: The Art of Italian Snack, aperitivo is a routine that can be built into our days, weeks and lives to cultivate community, family and even greater well-being. The practice gives us permission to just be and enjoy the little moments in life—the antithesis of America’s fast-paced, productivity-centered culture.

In this episode, we talk with Ferrari to better understand what constitutes the “magic” of aperitivo and how to recreate it at home. We discuss why gathering is fundamental to Italian life, how the ritual of aperitivo can help fulfill the basic need and desire to connect with others and how a little bit of alcohol can be part of a healthy, enriched life. Plus, Ferrari shares some of her most memorable aperitivo bites in Italy that fueled the inspiration behind the recipes in her book.

Our Aperitivo Coverage

From gear for spritzes and wine to splashes and snacks, here’s how to throw a proper aperitivo hour.

Master the art of Italian snacking with these aperitivo food recipes.

Aperitivo or digestivo? Here’s everything to know about these Italian spirits.

How to make the Aperol spritz, hero of aperitivo.

In the “5 Glasses in: Milan,” Writer-at-Large Jeff Porter explains how aperitivo culture means Negroni Sbagliatos and plenty of Franciacorta.
